explanation:
The correct calculation uses the area of a triangle formula: \(\frac{1}{2} \times 10\,\text{s} \times 20\,\text{m/s} = 100\,\text{m}\).  
The student likely calculated \(10\,\text{s} \times 20\,\text{m/s} = 200\,\text{m}\), treating the triangle as a rectangle.  
They misapplied the formula for area by omitting the division by 2 required for triangles.  
This directly stems from conflating the formulas for rectangles (base × height) and triangles (\(\frac{1}{2} \times\) base × height).  
The error is distinct from trapezoid-related misconceptions, as the graph forms a triangle (not a trapezoid) with a single sloped line.  
It also differs from averaging errors, as triangles inherently require division by 2 regardless of averaging logic.
